name: Moderator
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs: "The Youth Yelps for Help" by Graceanna of Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Morristown, New Jersey, "The Evolution of Opinion: How Political Views Shift with Age" by Mark of Seattle, and “Younger Progressives vs. Older Conservatives A Race Towards 2020” by Riley of Bush, and "Hot Topics for The Fiery Youth" by Dodge of Sequoyah School in Pasadena.
You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, March 5 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and a few Stat Nuggets. 
The next graph will be released in two days -- Friday, March 6, with moderation on Wednesday, March 11.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”  
You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, go to our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by type of graph. 
The link for the Stat Nuggets archives ishttps://tinyurl.com/StatNuggets.
Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, whose opinion on these political issues is more like the opinions of voters half her age, and Stefanie Geeve of Glen Ellyn, Illinois, who appreciated the wonderings about how gender, diversity, and population distribution might affect the graphs.

name: Grace R
comment info: These graphs show how different political issues are supported by different age groups. The political issues include automatic voter registration, free college tuition, greenhouse gas fees, and the belief that “the system is stacked against me.” The age groups range from 18 years old to 65 years old, and the opinions of the youngest and oldest groups surveyed are practically opposites. 18-29 year olds have an above average support for automatic voter registration at almost 90%, well over the average of 68% support. Those 65 years or older have a less than average support with approximately 61% support. The trend continues for the other issues. This makes sense as younger people are often dealing with paying for college and college debt, generally care more about the environment, and might feel that the “system is stacked against people like me” more than older generations as younger people could be struggling to find jobs compared to older people with more experience. I wonder how this data was collected and what other political issues different generations disagree on. One possible title for this graph could be “Generational Divide on Political Issues.”

name: Stedman Elementary 5th Graders
comment info:
5th graders at Stedman Elementary studied these graphs in class and made lists of what we noticed and wondered. 

We noticed: 
- Young people are more likely to want change.
- Older voters are less likely to want things to change.
- The older voters don’t seem to care as much about the things that mostly affect the younger voters. 
-Many younger people want college to be free.
-Over half of all age groups want greenhouse gas taxes; Greenhouse gas fees had the most agreement among the age groups.
-18-29 year olds disagree the most with 50+ year olds
-Most people supported most of these ideas, but a greater percentage of young people supported them than older people.

Wonder: 
-How would the graph change if we also separated out answers by race or gender? (Students especially wondered about the last question).
-Who did the researchers ask these questions? Was it a diverse group of people?
- How did they find the average of each issue?
-Do the older voters think younger voters will make bad decisions and not want automatic voter registration? 
- We wonder if the graph will change in the future (when the younger people are the older people), or if it will stay the same because people’s opinions change as they get older.
